title: Patriot Act panel discussion
full text:
The League of Women Voters of Anne Arundel County is sponsoring a panel discussion, "Public Dialogue:  Civil Liberties and the Patriot Act," at 7:45 p.m. April 13 at the Unitarian Church of Annapolis, 333 Dubois Road.
Panelists include David Rocha, counsel, American Civil Liberties Union, Jeanne Herrick-Stare, senior fellow for civil liberties and human rights, Friends Committee on National Legislation on the "con" side.
Representing the "pro" side will be: Harvey Eisenberg, assistant U.S. attorney general, director of the Anti-Terrorism Task Force for Maryland, and Brett Tolman, chief crime counsel of the U.S. Senate's Judiciary Committee.
Panelists will discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the Patriot Act which was passed in response to the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon in which nearly 3,000 people were killed.
The act, designed by Congress to enhance America's security against terrorism, has several segments that may "sunset" if Congress does not extend them. Some people who fear the act goes too far and impacts liberties traditionally extended to all Americans would like those provisions to end, while others believe that the act has gone far to increase safety and that it may need to go further to protect citizens.
The panel is open to the public.
